meanings.def: (in the UK) a place where students go to study or to receive training after they have left school
examples: She wanted to go to college to become a nurse.
Not all the lecturers are in college at any one time.
The college runs a course for would-be arts administrators.
The whole college was shocked to hear the news.
When I left school I went to secretarial college.

meanings.def: (in the US) a university where students can study for a degree after they have left school
examples: She was the first in her family to attend college.
He's hoping to go to college next year.
I graduated from college with an English degree.
She's now in her first year of college.
in college He got interested in politics when he was in college.
at college She's away at college in California.
out of college Their eldest son son is just out of college.
The college graduated 50 students last year.

meanings.def: a place where you can study for higher or more specialist qualifications after you finish high school
examples: My son has gone away to college.
I didn’t want to go to a large university.

meanings.def: one of the separate institutions that some British universities, such as Oxford and Cambridge, are divided into
(in the US) one of the main divisions of some large universities
examples: The history department is part of the College of Arts and Sciences.

meanings.def: the teachers and/or students of a college
a secondary school, especially one where you must pay
an organized group of professional people with special interests, duties or powers
examples: A college of cardinals will choose the next pope.
New guidelines have been released by the Royal College of Surgeons.
